sentence: Called inflation targeting, this new procedure essentially commits a country's central bank to hit an inflation target, usually expressed as a low, positive rate of inflation subject to some margin of error and some allowance for outside price shocks.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: New Zealand was the first country to adopt a formal inflation targeting regime back in 1990.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: The European Central Bank at least alludes to inflation targeting in its strategy statements, as do many countries in eastern Europe that aspire to join the European Union.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: At least ten emerging-market countries have adopted inflation targeting as a way to correct persistent inflation problems.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: In the last few months alone, Turkey, Switzerland, and South Africa have announced that they are switching to inflation targeting.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: When tallied up, the number of countries on either a formal or an informal inflation-targeting regime now approaches thirty.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Perhaps more meaningfully, there seems to be no country that has first tried inflation targeting and then abandoned it.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: While U.S. central bankers have often stressed the paramount importance of controlling inflation, the United States has never adopted a formal inflation target or an inflation-targeting regime.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: The Federal Reserve operates under the Federal Reserve Act, which requires the Fed to try to achieve maximum employment along with price stability.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: In a series of articles and books, Bernanke, Laubach, Mishkin, and Posen (1999) have proposed that the United States adopt an explicit inflation-targeting regime.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: Recognizing that the question of whether the United States should adopt inflation targeting is ultimately a congressional prerogative, one could still ask the normative question of whether the United States should go to inflation targeting.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: While inflation targeting seems to have been successful around the world, the preconditions for success may not be relevant for this country.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Given the strong U.S. commitment to controlling inflation, in the end there may be little difference between the way monetary policy already is practiced in the United States and the way it is practiced under the flexible, forward-looking inflation-targeting regimes followed by many countries.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Finally, although one can find economic circumstances in which inflation targeting will work well, it is also possible to imagine circumstances in which even forward-looking, flexible inflation targeting may not work so well, some of these circumstances from the fairly recent past of the United States.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Basic Aspects of Inflation Targeting Describing an inflation-targeting regime is straightforward.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: A country or its central bank commits to controlling inflation, with an explicit target rate and usually a tolerance band around this target rate.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Obvious price shocks such as indirect taxes, commodity prices, or interest rates themselves are usually excluded in the calculation of inflation targets.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Many inflation-targeting regimes permit flexibility for pursuing other goals, such as output stabilization, though the primary commitment of the central bank is clearly to control inflation.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Given the lags in monetary policy, many regimes also are forward-looking, in the sense that the central bank operates not against current inflation but expected inflation in the near future.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Three rationales normally are given for the adoption of inflation-targeting regimes: The provision of a nominal anchor for policy, transparency, and credibility.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: A nominal anchor may be required if countries permit their exchange rates to vary and if they do not target either the growth of monetary quantities or nominal income.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Governments or their central banks may need such an anchor to stabilize inflation, and they can generate the anchor by announcing an inflation target and then doing what they must do to hit that target.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: To the extent that monetary authorities can hit their target, central banks would also gain credibility, which many need after years of inflation.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: It is commonly argued that inflationary expectations are a key aspect of the inflation process.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: In lowering inflationary expectations, inflation targeting can itself help reduce inflationary pressures.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: One can also rationalize inflation targeting through another form of economic reasoning.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: Some years ago many believed, along with Milton Friedman, that stabilizing the growth of the money supply would lead to stable prices.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: But this approach is now generally discredited because shocks in the demand for money and an unstable transmission mechanism imply that stable growth of monetary aggregates could lead to quite unstable behavior for prices and real incomes.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: The next step was to follow Bennett McCallum (1988) and avoid inappropriate responses to shocks in the demand for money by having the central bank simply stabilize nominal income growth.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: But again, if there were shocks in this nominal income growth, say productivity shocks, stabilizing nominal income growth would not necessarily stabilize prices.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: The same productivity shocks have led to difficulties with the instrument rule proposed by John Taylor (1993), which requires either a predictable rate of growth of potential output or a predictable natural rate of unemployment.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: As these other procedures for conducting monetary policy have run into difficulty, academic economists have increasingly drifted to the straightforward view of Bernanke, Laubach, Mishkin, Posen and many others that, if central banks want to stabilize prices, they should just do that by inflation targeting.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: But the migration of academic economists to inflation targeting is nothing compared with the migration of actual real world countries to inflation targeting.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: The earliest and still most elaborate procedures were adopted by New Zealand, where the parliamentary government in 1990 began negotiating inflation targets with its newly independent central bank, making these targets public, and holding the bank responsible for hitting the targets.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Other regimes came later and were less elaborate, but by now a great many countries have regimes in which they publish inflation targets, have the central bank commit to meeting these targets, and comment on the progress in meeting the targets.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Because all central banks in the world are responsible for controlling inflation, it is reasonable to ask how explicit inflation-targeting regimes differ from non-targeting regimes.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Inflation-targeting regimes have explicit inflation targets, explicit commitments of the central bank to meet these targets, and less formal commitments to achieve other goals, such as output stabilization.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: On one side, even non-targeting countries often will be strongly committed to controlling inflation.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: On the other side, countries that target inflation flexibly and in a forward-looking manner may also strive to reduce output variability, perhaps because it helps to stabilize future inflation.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: All existing inflation targets around the world are for low, positive rates of inflation.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: For developed countries with stable inflation rates, the world average target rate of inflation is around 2 percent, with an acceptable band that normally ranges from 1 to 3 percent.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: Target levels are higher, but are promised to be stepped down gradually over time, for emerging-market countries that are trying to bring inflation down from very high levels.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: There is academic interest in targeting future price levels as opposed to inflation rates.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: The two approaches differ mainly in their response to past errors: Is the central bank to be held responsible for offsetting these past errors and getting the price level back on track or just for stabilizing inflation from this time forward?
label: LABEL_2

sentence: King (1999) shows that, if a long enough interval is given to hit the target, there may be little difference between a price level target and an inflation rate target.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: In any event, no country now targets the future price level.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: However, there could be an important difference between a target of a low positive rate of inflation and one of a zero rate of inflation.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Many potential inflation targeters ask, "Why not zero?"
label: LABEL_2

sentence: There are three reasons for targeting for an inflation rate above zero.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Try as they might, most countries do have some bias in their price indexes.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: But there may still be some irreducible upward bias in measuring inflation.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: The second reason for shooting at a rate of inflation slightly above zero is known as the zero bound problem.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: If a country's real interest rates are close to zero and its inflation rate is close to zero, its nominal interest rates will also be close to zero.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Since costs of holding cash are minimal, a central bank cannot push nominal interest rates much below zero.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: This means that countries that target for zero inflation could get in the bind of being unable to ease monetary policy in response to recessionary shocks.
label: LABEL_0

sentence: This forms a strong rationale for avoiding the danger in the first place, which can be helped by targeting for a low positive rate of inflation.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: The third reason for targeting a low positive rate of inflation is labor market inefficiencies.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: Akerlof, Dickens, and Perry (1996) argue that these can be lessened with some positive inflation.
label: LABEL_0

sentence: Essentially, employers can be spared the necessity of cutting workers' nominal wage when these workers' productivity falls below their real wage.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: While Akerlof, Dickens, and Perry make an empirical case for their views, others find little evidence that labor markets become less efficient when inflation drops to very low levels.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: While economists are still debating these issues, from a pragmatic standpoint many countries do seem to be gravitating toward a consensus on how inflation targeting should work.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: All inflation-targeting developed countries target a low positive rate, and emerging-market countries aspire to this kind of target.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Most countries target inflation in a flexible and forward-looking manner.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: Theoretical Pros and Cons From a theoretical perspective, one might think that inflation targets would be most valuable to countries with a history of bad inflation.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: One is to peg their exchange rate to some hard currency and essentially tie the hands of their central bank.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: The second route is to adopt an inflation target and to stick to it.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: If the prior inflation is very bad, as it often is in emerging-market countries, these targets might have to start at a high level and be worked gradually down as the central bank brings inflation under control.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Although inflation targeting is usually described as an antidote to past inflationary binges, it has also been suggested as a cure to potential deflation.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: Krugman (1998), for example, has argued that Japan, with nominal interest rates stuck at their floor of zero, can lower real interest rates and stimulate investment by having the Bank of Japan target a positive rate of inflation and do what it can to hit that target.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: Inflation-targeting regimes might also work well when a country undergoes what is known as a productivity shock.
label: LABEL_0

sentence: Suppose a wave of innovations makes productivity rise, pushing up output and lowering unit labor costs.
label: LABEL_0

sentence: For a time this shock might be reflected in higher-than-trend rates of growth of output and lower-than-trend rates of unemployment, making it difficult to rely on normal indicators of demand and supply growth in the conduct of monetary policy.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: In such circumstances, a cautious central bank might well just wait for signs of inflation to emerge, thwart the inflation if it occurs, and not rely as heavily on normal measures of aggregate demand growth or labor market tightness.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Such a central bank would, in effect, be following an inflation-targeting regime.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Although liberals in general have been very critical of inflation targeting (Galbraith, 1999), in this case inflation targeting would lead to exactly the type of monetary policy they would favor.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: But in some cases, inflation targeting might not work out so well.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: Suppose there were a recessionary shock to aggregate demand.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Because inflation normally responds slowly to such shocks, inflation targeters could respond in any of three ways.
label: LABEL_0

sentence: Strict inflation targeters, sometimes snidely called inflation nutters, might sit idly by and let the recession happen.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: Or, if inflation fell below target ranges, some central banks might take steps to boost inflation by expansionary monetary policy.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: They would clearly do this if deflation threatened, but they might do it even with low positive rates of inflation below target ranges.
label: LABEL_0

sentence: The third possible response involves flexible and forward-looking inflation targeting as is actually practiced in most countries.
label: LABEL_0

sentence: Because inflation usually responds slowly to output changes in recessions, flexible inflation-targeting regimes would be free to ease policy to stabilize output, much as would non-targeting central banks.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: Forward-looking central banks could even act affirmatively against recessions to prevent future inflation from falling below its target range.
label: LABEL_0

sentence: But even here the flexibility to be forward-looking and to pursue other goals is less than a commitment of the central bank to try to stabilize output or promote full employment.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: The exact importance of these other objectives remains in question, even for flexible and forward-looking inflation-targeting regimes.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Other instances in which inflation targeting might not work so well are negative supply shocks, such as most economies experienced in the mid-1970s when oil prices exploded.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: In these times, inflation rises just as output falls.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: The most flexible and competent central bank in the world would be faced with a difficult dilemma in such circumstances--forestall the recession by making inflation worse or limit the inflation by making the recession worse.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: In general, an inflation-targeting central bank would not have much of a choice.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: It would be forced to try to limit the inflation by contractionary policies, hence making the recession worse.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Even a flexible, forward-looking inflation-targeting central bank would not have much freedom in such a situation, because in the end the central bank would be evaluated much more on its success in meeting inflation targets than in meeting output growth targets.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: Hence, inflation targeting does not appear to solve all the problems central banks might face and cannot be prescribed as a panacea.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: It still might be a reasonable policy strategy for most purposes, and it still seems to be generally the proper approach for dealing with histories of inflation or deflation and, perhaps, with productivity shocks.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Actual Experience Theoretical arguments aside, many countries have used inflation targeting for most of the 1990s.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Hence we can do more than theorize: We can actually look at the inflation-targeting experience in several countries and see how it has worked out.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: They have compared a country's post-inflation-targeting history with its pre-inflation-targeting history, and they have compared outcomes in inflation-targeting countries with those in non-targeting countries.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: The time series studies have focused mainly on the three countries that have had the longest experience with inflation targeting--New Zealand (adopted in 1990), Canada (1991), and the United Kingdom (1992).
label: LABEL_2

sentence: According to the simple numbers, once these countries adopted inflation targeting, actual inflation has fallen in each country, and nominal interest rates have fallen, suggesting lower inflation expectations.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Real measures, such as the growth in output or unemployment, have either shown little change or worsened only slightly.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: Generally, unemployment rose as a country disinflated and then returned to its former average level, but sometimes not all the way there.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Ammer and Freeman (1995) estimated VAR models for real GDP, price levels, and real interest rates up to the adoption of a targeting regime and then simulated these models into the targeting era, comparing simulated values with actual values.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: They found that inflation fell below predictions in all three countries.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: A subsequent analysis by Freeman and Willis (1995) focused more intensely on interest rates.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: The authors noted that long-term nominal rates fell in all three countries following the adoption of inflation targeting but then came back up in the mid-1990s.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: The latter rises could either indicate that inflation-targeting regimes became less credible or simply reflect the fact that world interest rates were rising at this time.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Freeman and Willis worked out a model to disentangle the two effects and put most of the explanation for rising long-term nominal rates on the behavior of world interest rates, hence suggesting that inflation-targeting regimes remained credible.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: Mishkin and Posen (1997) noted that all three inflation-targeting countries reduced inflation before adopting a formal targeting regime.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: The achievement of inflation targeting, then, was to lock in the gains of earlier fights to stabilize prices.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: The authors also estimated VAR equations up to the adoption of inflation targeting and simulated these equations into the targeting period, now for six years.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: Just as in the earlier analysis of Ammer and Freeman, this analysis suggested that in all three countries the inflation targeting led to a drop in inflation and nominal interest rates.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: In Canada, the rate of growth of real GDP was down slightly; in the other two countries, there was no change in the rate of growth of real GDP.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Despite the fact that inflation had dropped in all three countries before the adoption of inflation targeting, these authors observed upward inflationary blips in New Zealand and Canada; so perhaps the achievement of keeping inflation under control should not be taken for granted.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Their results were buttressed by those of Kuttner and Posen (1999), whose VAR regressions for the United Kingdom found that inflation persistence was reduced by inflation targeting, as measured by inflation itself and by nominal interest rates.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: In Canada, there was no inflation persistence before or after inflation targeting as measured by inflation rates, though again targeting reduced inflation persistence as measured by nominal interest rates.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: In New Zealand, the results were the opposite--targeting reduced persistence as measured by inflation rates but seemed to increase it slightly as measured by nominal interest rates.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: They noted that the decade of the 1990s, when many countries went to inflation targeting, was a good one for economic outcomes: Many monetary regimes tried in this decade are likely to look good.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: In their formal work, these authors fit VAR models for twenty-three countries, nine inflation targeters and fourteen non-targeters.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: From these models, they deduced policymakers' aversion to inflation volatility.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: They found that inflation aversion rose in countries that adopted inflation targeting but only to the level of aversion already apparent in the policies of the non-targeting countries.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: At this point, there is very little difference between aversion to inflation in countries that target and countries that do not target inflation.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Taken together, the basic data, the time series tests, and the cross-section tests indicate that inflation targeting has seemed to succeed.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Inflation has dropped materially in the three countries with the longest experience with the regime, and all inflation-targeting countries are still content with inflation targeting, in some cases eight to ten years after its adoption.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Measures of inflation persistence also have dropped.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: A seeming weakness of inflation targeting is in its response to unemployment, but at this time one can find little evidence that unemployment has worsened in targeting countries.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: At the same time, inflation targeting has been adopted in the 1990s, a good decade for economic outcomes in most countries.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: It is unclear how inflation targeting would look in more difficult economic circumstances such as the 1970s.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Is Inflation Targeting Right for the United States?
label: LABEL_2

sentence: The hidden question in all this, of course, is whether the United States should go to a regime of explicit inflation targeting.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: First, the question of whether the United States does or does not adopt a formal inflation targeting regime is not up to the Federal Reserve.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: The Federal Reserve Act now requires the Fed to strive for maximum employment and balanced growth, along with price stability and moderate long-term interest rates.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Second, the Federal Reserve is strongly committed to controlling inflation, however formally this goal is specified in the Fed's mandate.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Countless official pronouncements and testimony affirm the importance of controlling inflation.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: As for actions, at least Cecchetti and Ehrmann find that the Fed's revealed inflation aversion is now as high as that of the formal inflation-targeting countries.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: Given this strong inflation aversion, ultimately there may be little difference between informal inflation targeting as practiced in the United States and flexible, forward-looking inflation targeting as practiced in many other countries around the world.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: That said, one could still ask the normative question of whether the United States should go to what I will call a more formal system of inflation targeting.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: Even if the present-day pragmatic Fed responds to exogenous rises in the growth of aggregate supply or drops in the non-inflationary rate of unemployment in a fully accommodative manner, inflation targeting may better communicate the strategy.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: For example, explicit inflation-targeting statements may help to make it clear that the Fed is really fighting inflation, not economic growth.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: Economic circumstances have been good in the 1990s, when countries have gone over to inflation targeting, and it is worth repeating that inflation targeting is no panacea.
label: LABEL_0

sentence: Moreover, there is a potential problem with inflation targeting even in good economic times.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: If forecasting inflation is difficult, even forward-looking inflation-targeting central banks may respond to inflationary shocks too late to ward off inflation.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Although there are several ways to forecast inflation, none may be that reliable.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: On the other side, one could imagine constructing leading indicators of inflation, but the experience until now is that not many of these are reliable either.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: One could also rely on market expectations of inflation, survey evidence, or other forecasts of inflation.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Without models or leading indicators, even forward-looking inflation targeting strategies may not work as well as advertised.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Conclusion Inflation targeting has many things going for it.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: This strategy of conducting monetary policy has been widely adopted around the world, and it has seemed to be successful in lowering inflation and perceptions of future inflation.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: It has a potential drawback in ignoring explicit consideration of output gaps and unemployment, but perhaps because it has been applied flexibly and in a forward-looking manner, in fact it has not seemed to generate more unemployment than other monetary regimes would have.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: For the United States, given the strong aversion to inflation already apparent in policy responses, there are various pros and cons, but it is not obvious that a more formal regime of inflation targeting will lead to very great differences in actual monetary policies.
label: LABEL_2
